Sure! Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

A devastating landslide in the Tibet Autonomous Region buried 83 workers from Tibet Huatailong Mining Development Co. Ltd. on Friday morning, local authorities reported. The incident occurred around 6 a.m. in Maizhokunggar County, east of Lhasa, and the victims included two Tibetans. The landslide, made up of 2 million cubic meters of mud, rock and other debris, extended three kilometers or almost two miles.

The US and Libyan governments held face-to-face talks in Tunisia, with the sole purpose of the US demanding that Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi "must go". The meeting was described as a "first step" by a Libyan government spokesman, with the US repeating its message that Gadhafi must end his rule. No details or comment were provided by Washington, and the Libian rebels have denied any talks with the government.

Sure! Here's a summary of the story in less than 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Canada has officially renounced the Kyoto Protocol, citing unworkable goals without the participation of the United States and China. Environment Minister Peter Kent states that the previous government signed onto the treaty without consideration of how it would be fulfilled, and that Canadians faced financial penalties equivalent to $1,600 per family. The country will still work to reduce greenhouse emissions and help negotiate a new framework for a global pact. The talks in Durban have launched a Green Climate Fund to help vulnerable countries deal with the effects of climate change.

She was arrested last year and sentenced in January, just before parliamentary elections. Rafsanjani, a powerful cleric and former parliament speaker, has been a vocal critic of the government and its violent crackdown against the opposition movement. Daughte"

Here's the story in under 150 words, while maintaining high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Colton Harris-Moore, the "Barefoot Bandit," pleaded not guilty to six federal charges. His lawyer said a draft plea agreement could be finished by the end of the day, with restitution amount negotiations still underway. Harris-Moore limped into court, attributed to an injury from a segignment, and his lawyer stressed that any book or movie deal generated will go to the victims. The fan base on Facebook is loyal and outspoken, with more than 50,000 fans, and he escaped from a Washington group home in 2008. His trial is set July 11.

A US Marine, Cpl. Trent D. Thomas, was sentenced to a rank reduction and discharge for his role in the death of an Iraqi civilian. Thomas was found guilty of kidnapping and conspury for his involvement in the April 2006 incident in Hamdaniya, Iraq. Seven Marines and a Navy medic were accused of killing 52-year- victim Hashim Ibrahim Awad, with prosecutors alleging that the group' leader, Sgt. Lawrence G. Hutchins III, shot the victim after dragging him from his home. Thomas changed his plea from guilty to not guilty, arguing that he was merely following orders. He will be discharged and demoted to the rank of private. The group leader, Hutchins, is awaiting trial on murder and conspiracy charges.

A poultry facility in Missouri was quarantined after a suspected case of bird flu was detected during routine testing. The facility is owned by Cargill Corp, which will euthanize up to 15,000 younger birds exposed to older turatoes that tested positive for bird flu antibodies. The state says it is extremely rare for humans to be affected by this type of bird flu, and tests may be back as early as Friday to confirm the presence of the virus. The discovery is concern for animals and preventing the spread to other herds, but no health risk poses for humans.

A mayoral candidate in Paris has proposed transforming the city's disused metro stations into unique attractions, such as subterranean nightclubs, swimming pools, and restaurers. The candidate commissioned illustrations showings the transformation of Arsenal metto station, which closed in 1939, into these different venue. The proposal is an attempt to revitalize the city' cre underground spaces and bring new ideas to the city. However, the candidate still lies far behind the favorite and fronter in the mayoral race.

Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

David Headley, born Daood Gilani, was sentenced to 35 years in prison for his role in the 2008 Mumbai attacks that killed 164 people. He changed his name in 2006 to facilitate surveance in India. Headley admitted conducting advance surveillview for the operation and cooperated with US authorities, which recommended the sentence. He received a Social SS Number in Pennsylvania in the late 1970s, and his name change helped him present himself as an American in India. Prosecutors said he cooperated with government efforts to combat terrorism, and the Indian government wants to conduct another trial.

Egyptian President Mohamed Morsy has condemned a deadly attack on soldiers at an army checkpoint in Sinai, promising to capture those responsible. At least 15 soldiers were killed and 9 others wounded when masked assailants attacked the checkpoint during the Muslim holy month of Ramadar. The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) have blided the attack as the work of Global Jihad terrorists, who attempted to infiltrate into Israel. A gunbattle between the attackers and armed forces ensued, with one of the armored personnel carriers explosion at the border and the other attacked as it entered Israeli territory. Hamas has condemned the attack, closing all border tunnuses connecting Gaza with Egypt. President Morsy has called on the military council to hold an emergency meeting, assuring that "Sinai is safe and fully under control" and those responsible will pay a high price.

A bomb blast in Kano, Nigeria killed at least four people and left several cars burning. The explosion occurred in a predominantly Christian area, and police have cordoned off the area and are searching for suspects and additional bombs. No responsible for the attack has been identified yet, with terrorism in Nigeria highlighted most recently by the kidnapping of over 2 200 school girls by Boko Haram.

NASA's Space Shuttle Discovery is set to launch next week on a mission to the International Space Station. The shuttle will carry a crew of seven astronauts and equipment to the station, including a treadmill named COLBERT, named after comedian Stephen Colbert. The mission will be Discovery's 37th to space and the 30th shuttle mission dedicated to assembly and maintenance of the space station. Launch is scheduled Tuesday at 1:36 AM ET, but may delay due to weather or technical concerns.

Atlanta's Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport discovered six unidentified men in a cargo truck during a random security sweep. Federal and state agencies found the men outside a cargo facility, unconnected to any airport terminals, as part of a routine exercise. The investigation is ongoing, with none of the men processed for removal from the US at this time. The men, from Mexico and El Salvador, had no apparent ill intent.

Lt. Gen. Karl Eikenberry, a career military officer, may become the next U.S. Ambassador to Afghanistan. If approved, he wants his wife, Ching, to accompate he wants her to come with him. However, the State Department rules dictate that Afghanistan is an "unacaced post" where family members are not allowed. Senator John Kerry is in favor of Eikenberry' taking his wife to the embass, but there is no immediate reaction from the State Department.

First Lady Michelle Obama will campaign for Democratic candidate Bruce Braley in Iowa next month, in what could be a boost for the candidate in one of the closest Senate races of the 2014 midterms. The Braley campaign confirms the plans, though no dates or locations have been set. The seat is currently open due to retiring Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin's absence, and Braley faces Republican state Sen. Joni Ernst, who has gained popularity with endorsements from well-known Republicans and her own popular ads. The first lady's appearance could inject momentum into the race, as the President's low approval rating in some areas may not make it possible for him to campaign himself.

Anes Subasic, a naturalized US citizen born in Bosnia, was found guilty of terrorism charges, including consptery to murder, kidnap, and injure people overseas. He was also convicted of providing material support to terrorists. This is the seventh conviction of a North Carolina group of men engaged in terror activities. Subasic worked to provide money, weapons training, and personnel to advance violent jihad from 2006 to 2009. He viewed his own country as the enemy and was part of a conspracy to commit violent acts against US service members and others abroad.

Sure! Here's the story in under 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Christine Rougoor, a 25-year-old woman from Ontario, recently went bungee jumping in Whistler, British Columbia. She was awarded the jump through a charity contest sponsored by 9Lives Adventures, an adventure company that helps people with disabilities achieve their extreme sport dreams. Rougoor, who has been paralized since a motocross accident in 2008, scrieyed as her blue bungee cord stretched over an icy river. She bounced up and down several times, strapped in her wheelch, before coming back safely. The experience provided a few seconds of freedom from worries and thoughts, Rougoor said. She would do it agin in a heartbeat. (Highlights: (1) Rougoor won the jump through a video contest sponsored by 9Lives Adventures (2) The company helps people with disabilities achieve their extreme sport dreams (3) Rougoor is paralized since a motocax accuirt in 2008 (4) The bungee jump provided a few seconds of freedom from worries and thoughts)

Here's the story in under 150 words, with high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

The 2014 midterm elections brought historic victories for Republicans and individual milestones. Tim Scott became the first African-American senator in the South since Reconstction and the first black candidate elected both houses. Mia Love, a first-generation American, is the first black Republican woman and first Haitian-American in Congress. Joni Ernst, a female combat veterer, became the first Senate representative from Iowa and the first female combat veterer. Shelley Moore Capito, a woman from West Virginia, became the state's first senator. Additionally, Tom Cotton, an Irairaveter, was elected to the Senate. The race in North Carolina was the most expensive ever, and the number of women in Congress will increase to 100 for the first time. Gina Raimondo, a Democrat, became Rhode Island;s first female governor, and Elise Stefanik, youngest woman ever, snagged a Congrial seat in New York.

Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

On Monday, a helicopter crash in western Afghanistan killed 10 Americans, including seven U.S. service members and three U.S. civilians. The crash occurred in Badghis province, where the military had just completed an operation to disrupt arms smuggling and narcotics trafficking. Low visibility due to thick dust caused the helicopter to strike a tall structure, resulting in the crash. No enemy fire was involved in either of the two helicopter incidents on Monday. The names of the dead service members will be released pending notification of next of kin.

Candace Eloph had been searching for her half-brother, given up for adoption in 1977, for years. She never thought she'd find him living across the street in Shreveport, Louisiana. Her mother, Joellen Cottrell, had longed to find her son, but failed over the years. After Eloph moved into the house, her neighbor, Jamie Wheat, revealed that her mother had given birth to him at Barksdale Air Force Base. They took a DNA test, and the results confirmed the sibs' relationship with a 99.995 percent probability. Eloph and Wheat plan to make up for lost time, with Wheat feeling a "weight lifted off'forward' new beginning."

Legendary musician George Clinton, 70, still tours and performs after decades in the industry. In a Red Chair interview, he introduces himself with a bark, just like his iconic P-Funk style. He reminisces about his biggest hits and the numerous musicians who have contributed to his success. Clinton acknowledges drug use but warns it's hard to do drugs and pay attention to money. He credits his loneness to his music and fans, and fights piracy issues to protect artists' work. Despite potential better decisions, Clinton hopes to continue his passion for years. (Highlights: P-Funk, Red Chair, longevity, drug use, piracy issues.)

Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands will abdicate on April 30, her 33rd anniversary of her coronation, to make way for her son Prince Willem-Alexander. In a televised speech, she assured the Dutch that she will still be able to mmooMntmmany of them after her departure. She expressed thanks for their faith in her throughout the years and emphasized the privilege of being able to put a big part of her life at the service of their country. Prince Willem-Alexander will succeed her to the throne and promises to devotionally serve the constitution and the people with all his talents. The Queen turns 75 on Thursday.

Marco Antonio Delgado, a prominent Texas attorney and former university trustee, has been charged with laundering over $600 million for a Mexican drug cartel. Prosecutors alleged that he conspired to launder the money and faces a maximum 20 year prison sentence if convicted. Delgado, who was once a trustee at Carnegie Mellon University, had also set up a scholarship for Latino students. His lawyer claimed that he is innocent and will go from there.

Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez has ordered an investigation into the death of Simon Bolivar, the country's founding hero, after exhuming his skeleton. Chavez suspects Bolivar may have been murdered, despite most historical accounts claiming tuberculosis killed him in 1830. The exhumed remains were shown on state television, with Chavez singing the national anthom. DNA tests will be performed on the remains and clothing found in the tomb. Bolivar is credited with spreading democratic principles in Latin America and leading the armies that liberated several nations.

Here's the story summarized in less than 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

At least four people were killed and nine injured in clashes in Saudi Arabia's Qatif region. The violence began on Monday and escalated during a funeral procession on Thursday. Interior Ministry spokesman Mansur al-Turki blamed unknown criminal sources for the casualties. The goal of the rioters is to achieve suspicious objectives dictated to them by their masters abroad, he said, without specifying which country. This incident is part of ongoing tension between Iran and the Sunni world, with Shiite protesters in Qatif urging the government to release prisoners and grant more rights earlier this year.

A wildfire in Michigan's Upper Peninsula has destroyed 97 structures, including 34 homes, a hotel, and a store. The Duck Lake Fire has burned over 22,000 acres since starting last week, with the state estimating it is about 51% contained. Crews have set up 40 miles of firelines to control the situation, but a lack of roads in the area has complicated efforts. The fire has taken its toll, with at least 97 structures on 39 different properties lost due to the blaze. Dry conditions have exacerbated the fire danger throughout the region.

Despite his lack of experience and lukewarm forecast, the campaign reached nearly $5,000 from 850 backers by Sunday evening. For $1, backers received a "thayu" on the website, while for $20, they got a potato-salad-themed hauku and signed jar of mayonnaise. This caused an uncomfortable moment for two individuals with prosticets and wheelchairs, who were not able to stand. The backlash on Twitter was immediate, as this was not the first time West has been criticized for such demands.

The English Premier League will adopt the vanishing spray used at the FIFA World Cup to help referees in the 2014/15 season. The biodegradable foam provides a visual 10-yard marker at free kicks to stop defenders encuring. Consultations with clubs and referees welcomed the idea, which has been used in Major League Soccer for years. The spray proved a hit at Brazil 2014 and will debut at Old Trafford on August 16.

A private jet crashed near Freeport, Bahamas, killing all nine people on board. The flight originated from Nassau, and the cause of the crash is not yet clear. The Andrew Young Foundation confirmed that Dr. Myles and Mrs. Ruth Munroe, senior and co-pastors of Bahamas Faith Ministorgraphics International Fellowship, were among the victims. The organization expressed that the Global Leadership Forum will continue as planned, as this was what Dr. Munroe would have wanted. The Federal Aviation Administration will investigate the crash.

The U.S. Open will get retractable roofs for its two main stadiums, starting with Arthur Ashe Stadium as early as 2016. The cost of the project, which includes new and bigger show courts, is expected to hit $550 million. The retractable roof over Arthur Ashe alone will be over $100 million. The men's governing body in the U.S. will self-finance the project. Women's No. 1 Serena Williams and other players welcome the news, which likely means the tournament won't enter a 15th day. Jo-Wilfried Tsonga has pulled out of the U.S. Open due to a knee injury.

Ltd., a subsidiary of China National Gold Group Corp. The landslide, made of about 2 million cubic meters of mud, rock and other deber, extended three kilometers (almost two miles).

The US and Libyan governments held face-to-face talks in Tunisia, with the sole purpose of the meeting being for the US to demand that Libian leader Moammar Gadhafi "must go." The Libian government spokesman called the talks "a first step," while a US official called them a "one-time message" and not negotiations. The meeting was conducted by three American envoos and four Libian officials, with no details or comment from Washington on the report. The US officials repeated their demand that Gadhafi step away, which the Libian officials heard and understood, according to the US official.

Canada has officially renounced the expiring Kyoto Protocol, citing unworkable goals without the participation of the United States and China. Environment Minister Peter Kent stated that Canada will continue to reduce its greenhouse emissions, but the previous government should not have agreed to Kyoto. The decision was criticized by the opposition New Democratic Party, who accused the government of standing up for big polluters at the expatter of ordinary Canadians. The government is self-imposed goal is well below the Kyoto targets, but it is "well on our way" to reducing emissions by 17% over 2005 levels by 2020.

Faezeh Hashemi, daughter of former Iranian president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, has been sentenced to six months in prison for taking part in anti-government protests. She has arrived at Evin prison, where she will carry out her sentence in a relatively comfortable section. Rafsanjani, a powerful critic of the government, has been one of the wealthiest and most politically powerful men in Iran. His daughter's arrest and sentence reflect the government's crackdown on dissension.

The loss of a second Boeing 777 in 131 days threatens Malaysia Airlines with a potentially fatal blow, as it struggles to overcome industry and consumer fallout after the disappearance of Flight 370. The latest flight, MH17, crashed in eastern Ukraine, and early speculation suggests it may have been shot at an altitude of more than 30,000 feet. The airline must share every piece of information and every piece of data, including the decision making process, to prevent further wreckage and loss of life. The airline's handling of Flight 370 has already caused significant hit to confidence, and the airline must discuss possible mistakes made and what they've done better since then. The tragedy may require a government rescue to save the company from financial disaster, as it has faced increased competition and financial troubles in recent years.

A wind turbine blade in Conisholme, Lincolnshire was destroyed, and a UFO was blamed for the damage. Locals reported seeing strange lights in the sky, and a tabloid newspaper claimed that a UFO hit the turbine. However, the damage may have been caused by mechanical failure or ice thrown from a neighboring turbine. The expert Dr. Peter Schubel concluded that it was not a bird and the force could be a 10-ton load. The case is similar to that of Mulder and Scully, and the public is left to decide between an Alien cont. or simple mechanical failure.

His lawyer, John Henry Browne, stated that attorneys are working on the details of a plea agreement and that a draft could be finished by the end of the day. The trial is set to begin on July 11. Harris-Moore is accused of stealing various modes of transportation while eluding capture, and possible book and movie deals are in the works. His lawyer stressed that any money generated from such deaks will be restituted to the victoms.

A poultry facility in Missouri has been quarantined after a suspected case of bird flu was detected during routine testing. The facility is owned by Cargill Corp, which will euthanize up to 15,000 younger turkeys as a precaution. The older birds will be harvested at another location and their meat poses no health risk. Tests may be back as early as Friday, and the state says it is extremely rare for humans to be affected by this type of bird flu. The focus is on animals and preventing the spread to other animal herds.

A mayoral candidate in Paris has proposed transforming the city's disused metro stations into vibrant spaces, such as swimming pops, nightclubs, and art installments. The candidate has commissioned illustrations to show how Arsenal, one of the city' gost metro stops, could be used. The proposal is to ask Parisians for their own ideas on how to transform the vacent subterranean spaces. Despite the candidate', far behind the frontruder in the mayoral race, the idea is still intriging and pretty.

The trial of Kaing Guek Eav, a former math teacher and born-again Christian, resumed in a Cambodian courtroom on Monday. Duch, as he is better known, is accused of overseeing the torture and killing of over 15,000 men, women, and children during the Khmer Rouge''regime. Prosecutors paint a gruesome picture of inmets who were electroc, Whipped, and beaten to death. Duch ran a prison where victims were shackled to iron bets and tortured before being beaten to death. Many of the victims were military officials or Communist Party members targeted for not going along with the Khmer Rouge''s philosophy. Duch faces charges of crimes against humanity, war crimes, torture, and murder, and could face five years to life in prison if convicted. The trial is significant as it is the first for a former Kherm Rouge leader and serves as a message that such atrocities cannot be ignored.

Here is a summary of the news in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

David Headley, a U.S.-Pakistani man, was sentenced to 35 years in prison for his role in the 2008 Mumbai attacks that killed 164 people, including six U.S. citizens. He changed his name from Daood Gilani to David Headley in 2006 to facilitate advance surveillance in India. Prosecutors agreed not to seek the death penalty in exchange for his plea on terrorism charges, as he provided extensive intelligence about terrorist activities. Headley cooperated with authorities investigating both terror plots, and his sentencing recommendation was fair due to his significant cooperation. The U.S. government will not send him to any other country, while the Indian government wants to conduct another trial. His name change and cooperation with authorities have made news headlines.

Egyptian President Mohamed Morsy condemned a deadly attack on soldiers at the Rafah border crossing in Sinai, killing 15 soldiers and wounding 9 others. The attack was blamed on Global Jihad terrorists associated with the Israel Defense Forces. Morsy vowed to capture those responsible, stating that Sinai is safe and fully under control. The attack was not attributed to anyone, but terrorism in Nigeria has been in focus since the kidnapping of over 2 200 school girls by Boko Haram.

Food festivals around the world celebrate unique and unusual cuisines, from Spam in Hawaii to roadkill in West Virginia. These festivals showcase the diversity of food cultures and offer a chance to experience outlandish delights. Participants engage in mashed potato wrestling, scorpion tails, and even giant omelet celebrations. Festivals like Räbechilbi in Switzerland highlight the artistic turnips, while Clinton, MT' Testy Festy celebrates bull testicles. These messy festivals provide an opportunity to taste new foods and experience the local history and traditions.

NASA's Space Shuttle Discovery is set to launch next week to the International Space Station, carrying a crew of seven astronauts and equipment. One of the astronauts, Nicole Stott, will remain on the space station as a flight engineer. The mission will also include delivering the Combined Operational Load Bearing External Resistance Treadmill, named COLBERT after comedian Stephen Colbert. The module was given the name Tranquility instead. The mission will be Discovery's 37th to space and the 30th shuttle mission dedicated to assembly and maintenance of the space station.

Google is rolling out a new version of Google Glass, its wearable tech device, to current testers. The new Glass will work with eyglasses or shades and include an ear bud to rep repel speaker issues. Testers will have 60 days to decide if they want the new Glass and will be able to invite three friends to join the program. The upgrade is expected to improve the device's compatibility with other eyeglasses. The current $1,500 price will still be applicable for testers. Google has not yet announced when Glass will be available to the general public.

Six unidentified men were found hidden in a cargo truck at Atlanta's airport during a random security sweep. They were handed over to federal agencies and were later revealed to be illegal immigrants from Mexico and El Salvador. No intent to harm the US was found. The investigation is ongoing and they have not been processed for removal. The men were discovered outside a cargo facility as part of a routine exercise.

The upcoming papal election has sparked calls for greater female representation in the Catholic Church, despite the fact that women are not allowed to be ordained as priors. The story of Pope Joan, a mythical female pointe, has been used to boost good causes, but historians say it is nonsense. Women currently occupy important lay positions in Catholic social and relief organizations, but they have no direct say in who the next pope will be. The Vatican's hierarchy is male-dominated, and the church is not a democratic society. Calls for a female pope may be loud, but it is unlikely to happen soon.

A Maryland man died last month after receiving a tainted organ in 2011. The donor was found to have rabies, and three other recipients in Florida, Georgia, and Illinois are being treated with anti-rabies shots. Doctors knew the donor had encephalitis but did not test for rabies before the transplant. Organ donors are not routarily tested for rabies, even if the donor shows signs, as it is extremely rare and many lifesaving organs would be lost if donors are tested. However, some doctors are considering new rules to help doctors decide what to do with organs when the donor has died of encephalitis of unknown cause.

Sure, here is a summary of the news article in less than 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

African-American atheists exist, but are often overlooked in media and secular communities. Many blacks identify as religious, and the church is tied to tradition, history, and culture. Openly identifying as an atheist can be difficult, and finding other black atheisists can be next to impossible. However, online internet communities have made it easier for black nonbelievers to find eachother. Experiences in the secular community as a black atheist range from welcomed to ignored, and there lacks diversive representation in organized events, leadership, and media coverage. We will continue to grow and lead the charge for change, and our presence will bolster the recognition we deserve.

Survivors of the sunken South Korean ferry visited their high school in Ansan, where they sobbed as they walked past images of their classmates. The ferry, which was carrying 425 people, sank on April 16, and the death toll has risen to 228 with 74 missing. The country's president apologized for the initial response to the traaster, and authorities have arrested three people for destroying evidence connected to the probe. The investigation is also looking into possible dereliction of duty. The ferry disaster has left the nation in sorrow and has raised questions about the country's safety practices.

BP has implemented new safety systems for offshore drilling, ahead of its competitors, following the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster.
